question:
Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 35-year-old male anesthesiologist presents to the occupational health clinic after a needlestick exposure while obtaining an arterial line in a patient with cirrhosis. In addition to a standard bloodborne pathogen laboratory panel sent for all needlestick exposures at his hospital, additional hepatitis panels are ordered upon the patient's request. The patient's results are shown below:

HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab: Negative/Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): Negative
Hepatitis C antibody: Negative
Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb): Positive
Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM): Negative
Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG): Positive

What is the most likely explanation of the results above?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: In an occupational health evaluation following a needlestick sustained by a 35-year-old male anesthesiologist while placing an arterial line in a patient with cirrhosis, interpretation of the comprehensive serologic panel is guided by established hepatitis B virus (HBV) serology algorithms. The patient’s HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab is Negative/Negative and the Hepatitis C antibody is Negative, excluding common coinfections. Critically, his Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is Negative, his anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) is Positive, and his anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) is Negative with a concomitant Positive anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG). The absence of HBsAg and HBc IgM rules out acute HBV infection, while the presence of HBc IgG confirms prior exposure to HBV; the detected HBsAb indicates seroconversion after antigen clearance. This serologic constellation is canonical for resolved past exposure rather than vaccination-only immunity, thereby supporting the conclusion of Past Hepatitis B infection.
content.source_2: In the context of post-exposure assessment for a 35-year-old male anesthesiologist, the serologic profile—HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive—maps onto the natural history of HBV infection wherein successful recovery is characterized by antigen clearance and antibody development. Specifically, HBsAg negativity indicates the absence of ongoing surface antigenemia, HBc IgM negativity excludes the acute phase, HBc IgG positivity denotes prior exposure, and HBsAb positivity reflects post-clearance seroconversion conferring protective immunity. In an immunocompetent adult, this pattern is consistent with convalescence leading to durable recovery, rather than chronic carriage or isolated vaccine response. These data support the diagnosis of Past hepatitis B infection with recovery.
content.source_3: Following a needlestick exposure, the serologic results in this 35-year-old male anesthesiologist—HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive—demonstrate functional protection against HBV predicated on the presence of anti-HBs. In occupational health practice, a Positive HBsAb is the principal marker used to ascertain immunological protection against HBV, irrespective of the source of immunity, provided there is no concurrent HBsAg positivity or IgM core reactivity suggesting active infection. The lack of HBsAg and HBc IgM confirms no current infection, and the detected HBsAb indicates protective immunity relevant to post-exposure risk stratification. Therefore, the serologic profile substantiates the conclusion of Immunized against Hepatitis B.
content.source_4: For a 35-year-old male anesthesiologist evaluated after a needlestick while placing an arterial line in a patient with cirrhosis, the integrated serologic findings—HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive—indicate prior HBV exposure with subsequent development of adaptive immunity. Persistence of HBc IgG serves as a durable marker of previous infection, absence of HBc IgM and HBsAg excludes current acute or chronic replicative disease, and the presence of HBsAb signifies neutralizing antibody capable of preventing reinfection. This immuno-serologic pattern is typical of resolved natural infection and confers protective status at the time of exposure assessment. The most appropriate conclusion is Past hepatitis B infection, now immune.
content.source_5: In the post-needlestick evaluation of this 35-year-old male anesthesiologist, the laboratory constellation—HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive—aligns with resolved HBV infection and sustained immune protection. The Negative HBsAg excludes contemporaneous antigenemia, the Negative HBc IgM rules out acute infection, the Positive HBc IgG confirms remote exposure, and the Positive HBsAb denotes protective immunity acquired after viral clearance. Within occupational health risk management, this profile differentiates natural, resolved infection from vaccine-only seropositivity and indicates low susceptibility to HBV following the recent exposure. The final diagnosis is Previous Hepatitis B infection, now immune.
